Organs/Tissues: Vascular endothelium, basic 2D or small 3D cultures under flow; can apply to many tissues (e.g. endothelium-lung, endothelium-tumor). Each channel is separate (no shared membrane).
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Replicates shear flow for normal vascular conditions or disease states (inflammation, cancer metastasis, etc.).
Cell Source: Any cell lines or primary cells that can adhere in microchannels. Also small organoids or spheroids placed in the channel flow path.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (each channel can hold a distinct cell type or condition), but no direct membrane interface. Co-culture possible if seeded in the same channel or bridging material.
Stromal Cells: Yes, if embedded in a 3D gel or seeded along with primary cells in the channel.
Tissue-resident Immune: Possible if included in the same channel or 3D matrix.
Circulating Immune: Yes, can flow immune cells (e.g. T-cells, PBMCs) through one or both channels to observe adhesion/migration.
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Limited in a single device (two channels remain separate). For multi-tissue interplay, can connect multiple chips externally.
Air-Liquid Interface: Not standard. Typically fully liquid-filled channels. ALI would require modifications.
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, can coat channels with ECM proteins or introduce a thin 3D hydrogel. Channels can be partially filled with collagen gel, for instance.
3D Scaffold: Yes, small scaffolds or spheroids can be placed in channel. Flow gently bathes them. Often used for small 3D tumor or tissue aggregates.
Notable Features: Simple, user-friendly. Two parallel channels for side-by-side experiments. Low absorption (COP). High optical clarity.
Plate/Format (Throughput): Slide-like chip. Typically 2 conditions per chip, multiple chips in parallel for moderate throughput. Not a multi-well plate format.
Max Culture Duration: Days to weeks under continuous flow, depending on cell viability. Low evaporation & low drug absorption prolong viability.
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, optically transparent polymer. Standard microscope stage. Confocal/fluorescence possible.
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, from channel outlets. Low volume, easy to switch media or collect effluent.
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Feasible via trypsin flush or lysis. Typically in situ imaging/staining is favored.
Readouts - Whole Tissue: In situ. Possibly open chip by cutting, but not designed to open easily. Usually do on-chip analysis or flush out 3D constructs if small.
Readouts - TEER: Not integrated. Could attempt external electrodes in each channel. More common to do permeability assays.
Readouts - MEA: No. Not embedded. External MEA or custom integration needed for electrophysiology.
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No built-in. Off-chip or custom solutions for O2/pH if needed.
Dead Volume: Very low in microchannels. Minimally delayed media changes. Efficient reagent usage.
Perfused: Yes. Core feature. Continuous or intermittent flow via external pumps. Allows shear stress studies.
Gas Mix Controlled: Typically in standard incubator. COP is gas-impermeable, so rely on pre-equilibrated media or external environment.
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate changes or media switching possible at any time. External pump/valve control.
model_availability: Commercial from Beonchip. Users purchase chips (box of 10). Provide own cells & pumps.

Organs/Tissues: Barrier models: gut epithelium vs endothelium, BBB, alveolar-capillary interface, tumor–endothelium, etc.
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Emulates tissue–vascular or epithelial–stromal interfaces in healthy or diseased states.
Cell Source: Any adherent cells that form barrier layers on membrane. E.g. epithelial, endothelial, fibroblasts, tumor cells, etc.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes. Distinct cell populations can be seeded on each side of the membrane for co-culture (endothelial vs epithelial).
Stromal Cells: Yes, can embed fibroblasts in a hydrogel on one side. Or place them on the membrane layer with parenchymal cells.
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, can localize immune cells in the tissue channel. They can traverse membrane if pores allow.
Circulating Immune: Yes, immune cells can be perfused in the vascular channel to study transmigration.
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Direct membrane-based interaction. Each channel is separately perfused, but molecules/cells pass through pores.
Air-Liquid Interface: Not typically. Both channels are liquid-filled. ALI would require a different chip (e.g. TransFlow).
Extracellular Matrix: Can coat membrane with ECM or embed one channel in collagen gel. Membrane fosters cell attachment.
3D Scaffold: Possible if one channel is partially filled with a 3D matrix. Usually used for 2D barrier, but 3D can be integrated.
Notable Features: Ideal for barrier function, transendothelial migration, co-culture of two tissues with separate flows.
Plate/Format (Throughput): Slide-based chip. 2 compartments per chip. Parallel usage for moderate throughput. Not multi-well plate form.
Max Culture Duration: Days–weeks with continuous perfusion. Maintains stable barrier if cells remain healthy.
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, transparent polymer + thin membrane. High resolution imaging from top/bottom if membrane is optically friendly.
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, each channel has in/out. Can measure apical vs basolateral secretions.
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Trickier due to membrane. Possibly flush or cut open. Typically do on-chip staining or lysis.
Readouts - Whole Tissue: In situ or carefully remove membrane if physically feasible. Usually end in immunostaining on chip.
Readouts - TEER: Not built-in. Could place electrodes in each channel. Permeability assays more common by default.
Readouts - MEA: No integrated. Would need custom approach for electrical readouts.
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No. Rely on off-chip or custom sensor integration. Membrane-based barrier assays use tracer dyes.
Dead Volume: Low. Two microchannels each ~ tens of µL. Minimizes reagent usage, speeds media exchange.
Perfused: Yes, dual perfusion. Each channel can have independent flow, mimicking blood vs tissue compartments.
Gas Mix Controlled: Via incubator or pre-equilibrated media. No direct gas exchange through walls. Good for stable O2 conditions.
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate & composition changes are easy with external pumps. Membrane fosters dynamic crosstalk.
model_availability: Commercial from Beonchip. Sold in 10-pack. Used widely for barrier models, user provides cells.

Organs/Tissues: Skin-on-chip, lung alveolar (ALI), or any 3D tissue in the top well with perfusion from below. Also suitable for organoids or slices placed in the well.
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Recreates alveolar-capillary or skin-blood interface (physiology) or diseased states (cancer infiltration, infections, etc.).
Cell Source: Various: epithelial, keratinocytes, alveolar cells in top well, endothelium or stroma in bottom channel. Tissue slices, organoids, or 2D monolayers in well.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, top well can hold 3D culture or co-cultures; channel below can host endothelial cells. Membrane in between. ALI possible above the well.
Stromal Cells: Yes, embed fibroblasts in a hydrogel in the well, while other cell types line the membrane or channel.
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, can incorporate immune cells into the 3D tissue or well environment.
Circulating Immune: Yes, perfuse them in the bottom channel for infiltration across the membrane to the well.
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, fluid exchange across the membrane. Tissue in well can communicate with endothelial side under flow.
Air-Liquid Interface: Primary chip supporting ALI. Top well can be exposed to air, bottom channel perfused with medium.
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, well can be filled with collagen or Matrigel 3D matrix. Membrane fosters cellular attachment or layering.
3D Scaffold: Core design. Tissue slice, organoid, or 3D hydrogel in the open well. Flow from below for nutrients.
Notable Features: Hybrid of Transwell + microfluidics. Great for lung or skin models under ALI. Simplifies seeding in a well format.
Plate/Format (Throughput): Single open-well chip. Low throughput. Good for advanced 3D or ALI studies. Parallel usage possible.
Max Culture Duration: Days–weeks. ALI or 3D tissues remain viable with continuous perfusion from below. Minimizes necrosis.
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, transparent base. Observe from below or top. The well is accessible for confocal, etc.
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: From the outlet of bottom channel. Top well can also be sampled easily with a pipette.
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Relatively easier for top well tissue (like removing organoids). Membrane removal can be attempted if needed.
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Often do in situ. Tissue or gel can be lifted out from the well if not strongly attached to the membrane. Membrane can be cut out for histology.
Readouts - TEER: Feasible with external electrodes in top well vs. bottom channel. Not pre-integrated.
Readouts - MEA: No. Typically for ALI or 3D. Electrical readouts need a custom solution.
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: Not standard. Add external sensors or do sampling assays.
Dead Volume: Minimal in channel. The top well can hold more volume like a standard well, still relatively small compared to macroculture.
Perfused: Yes, bottom channel is continuously perfused. The well can be static or gently refreshed from above.
Gas Mix Controlled: Top well can be open to incubator air (ALIs). Bottom channel is sealed. Gas composition relies on media & external environment.
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Flow rate adjustments below. The well environment can be changed by pipetting or switching out medium if needed.
model_availability: Commercial from Beonchip. Ideal for ALI or large 3D tissue culture in open well + microfluidic perfusion.

Model: Be-Gradient (Central 3D Chamber + Two Perfusion Side Channels)
Organs/Tissues: Tumor microenvironment, angiogenesis, chemotaxis assays, organoids needing stable or gradient conditions (e.g. brain organoids, vascular infiltration).
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Generate stable gradients for morphogen-driven tissue development or pathological gradients (e.g. oxygen, chemo-attractants).
Cell Source: Any 3D culture: tumor cells, stem cells, primary tissues embedded in ECM. Co-culture with fibroblasts, endothelium in side channels, or placed in the central chamber.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes, central 3D cell-laden matrix plus endothelial or other cells in the side channels. They can interact at the matrix interface.
Stromal Cells: Yes, fibroblasts or mesenchymal cells in the central matrix or combined with parenchymal cells. Side channels can also hold stroma or endothelium.
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, embed immune cells in the gel or place them in side channels to migrate into the central region.
Circulating Immune: Yes, flow them through a side channel, observe infiltration into the 3D tissue. Ideal for immune–tumor infiltration studies.
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Central tissue can crosstalk with side channel tissues/fluid. If multiple cell types in separate channels, paracrine signals cross the gel interface.
Air-Liquid Interface: No, typically all compartments are fluid-filled. Not designed for ALI.
Extracellular Matrix: Core concept: a 3D hydrogel in the central chamber for cell embedding. The side channels remain fluid-flow paths.
3D Scaffold: Yes. The central region is specifically for 3D constructs (gel plus cells). Typically suitable for tumor spheroids, organoids, etc.
Notable Features: Stable or dynamic gradient formation across the 3D chamber. Allows study of invasion, angiogenesis, directed migration.
Plate/Format (Throughput): Single chip with a central chamber. Typically 1 experiment per chip. Parallel use for moderate throughput.
Max Culture Duration: Days–weeks, with continuous flow in side channels. Maintains viability in the 3D core. Reduces necrotic core in organoids.
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, transparent polymer. Confocal imaging through the central gel. Real-time observation of gradient effects.
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Side channels can be sampled. The central region is a gel, so direct sampling might be more complex (requires micropipette insertion).
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Gel removal is possible, though delicate. Usually in situ immunostaining or flush out if partially fluid. Could dissect the chamber or do lysis for molecular assays.
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Usually in situ confocal or fix and stain the entire matrix. Physical removal is possible but tricky. Some have cut open the chip post-fixation.
Readouts - TEER: Irrelevant usually, no discrete barrier membrane. Permeability or migration assays used instead.
Readouts - MEA: No built-in electrodes. Typically focusing on morphological/chemotaxis readouts, confocal imaging.
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No standard sensors. Gradients and media composition measured externally or via fluorescence. Could add custom sensors.
Dead Volume: Low channel volume. Central gel is small volume. Minimizes reagent use, ensures quick gradient changes.
Perfused: Yes, side channels are continuously perfused. Flow creates the gradient. Central chamber is primarily static gel, fed by diffusion.
Gas Mix Controlled: In an incubator or controlled environment. No direct gas exchange through walls, so rely on medium for O2. Stable gradient of O2 or other factors is feasible.
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, can dynamically change flows or solute in side channels to alter gradient. Gradual ramp or on/off possible.
model_availability: Commercial from Beonchip. Good for 3D cell culture with stable or dynamic chemo-gradients. User seeds gel & sets up pump.
